title: Schedule
text:
Assignments
Below are assignment due dates for the semester. You can find details and assignment instructions in the relevant week on the schedule.

Homework
Homework will be due by Sunday at 11:59pm. You will have at least 11/12 days to complete each homework assignment.


Labs
Labs will be due on Fridays at 11:59pm. You will start the lab during your scheduled lab section.


Exams
There will be two exams on the dates TBD.

title: Integrating Machine Learning into Economics
text:
Introduction

Appreciation for Machine Learning

Gained from experience in technology

Evolution in Economics

Initially rare in economics and social sciences
Now prevalent in PhD dissertations

title: Integrating Machine Learning into Economics
text:
Traditional Economics Research

Empirical Focus

Use of data with models
Often on small datasets

Policy Questions

Emphasis on cause and effect
Examples:

Impact of raising prices
Effects of increasing minimum wage

title: Integrating Machine Learning into Economics
text:
Early Machine Learning Focus

Prediction and Classification

Classifying images (e.g., cats vs. dogs)
Reliance on labeled datasets

Black Box Models

Performance measured by accuracy on test data
Limited understanding of underlying processes

title: Integrating Machine Learning into Economics
text:
Gap Between ML and Economics

Different Objectives

ML: Prediction accuracy
Economics: Causal inference and “what-if” scenarios

Challenges

Lack of tools addressing causal questions in ML
Difficulty in assessing unseen counterfactuals

title: Integrating Machine Learning into Economics
text:
Bridging the Gap

Developed Conceptual Frameworks

Connected ML innovations with economic research needs

Created Tools and Software

Personalized policy development
Widely adopted by social scientists and tech firms

Applications

Reanalyzing experiments
Administrative data analysis

title: Integrating Machine Learning into Economics
text:
Applications of Integrated ML

Personalized Medicine

Administer drugs to those who benefit most

Economic Policies

Assess effects of layoffs on different demographics

Industry Adoption

Integration into A/B testing platforms
Improved decision-making in tech companies

title: Integrating Machine Learning into Economics
text:
Promoting Interdisciplinary Collaboration

Recognized Need

Engineers understanding social implications
Ethicists contributing to technological solutions

Approach

Solve real problems collaboratively
Engage deeply across disciplines

Outcomes

Better handling of content moderation
Addressing differential impacts on groups

title: Integrating Machine Learning into Economics
text:
Human-Centered AI Institute

Establishment

Founded at Stanford in 2017

Vision

Advance AI research responsibly
Focus on ethics and societal impact

Goals

Foster interdisciplinary research
Educate on responsible AI use

title: Integrating Machine Learning into Economics
text:
Educational Initiatives

Identified Gaps in Learning

Engineers lacked exposure to real-world problems

Curriculum Development

Combined technical skills with domain knowledge

Student Outcomes

Better prepared for industry challenges
More holistic understanding of AI applications

title: Integrating Machine Learning into Economics
text:
Conclusion

Integration is Key

Combining ML with economics enhances both fields

Multidisciplinary Approaches

Essential for responsible AI development

Future Directions

Continue educating and bridging gaps
Foster collaborations for societal benefit

title: Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
text: This course provides an introduction to machine learning and related methods for big data from an economics perspective. Students will learn modern estimation methods for high-dimensional data, with a focus on causal inference and prediction problems in economics, business, and related fields. Through programming assignments and a final empirical project, students will apply machine learning techniques to real-world data.

title: Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
text: This course provides an introduction to machine learning and related methods for big data from an economics perspective. Students will learn modern estimation methods for high-dimensional data, with a focus on causal inference and prediction problems in economics, business, and related fields. Through programming assignments and a final empirical project, students will apply machine learning techniques to real-world data.

title: Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
text:
Learning Outcomes
By the end of the course, students should be able to:

Apply machine learning methods to estimate causal effects in experimental and observational settings.
Solve prediction problems in economics using machine learning techniques.
Understand the uses, strengths, and limitations of machine learning for answering economic questions.
Implement machine learning algorithms using Python/R.
Analyze and interpret economic data using machine learning methods.
Conduct an empirical research project utilizing machine learning techniques.

title: Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
section: Week 1-2: Introduction to Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
text:
Week 1-2: Introduction to Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics

Overview of big data and machine learning.
Key differences between traditional econometric techniques and machine learning methods.
Bias-variance trade-off and its implications for econometric models.

Readings: Introduction to Statistical Learning (ISL), Chapter 1; Taddy, M. (2019), Chapter 1 from Business Data Science.

title: Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
text:
Week 3-4: Supervised Learning and Regression

Overview of supervised learning and its relevance to economic data.
Linear regression and its extensions in machine learning contexts.

Lab: Implementing regression methods using Python/R.
Readings: ISL, Chapters 2-3; Taddy, M. (2019), Chapter 3.

title: Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
text:
Week 5-6: Classification Methods

Introduction to classification problems, logistic regression, and discriminant analysis.
Decision trees and their use for classification in economics.

Lab: Logistic regression, LDA, QDA, and decision trees in Python/R.
Readings: ISL, Chapters 4 and 8.

title: Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
section: Week 7-8: Resampling Methods and Model Selection
text:
Week 7-8: Resampling Methods and Model Selection

Cross-validation and bootstrap methods for model evaluation.
Choosing the best model for economic data applications.

Lab: Implementing cross-validation and model selection in Python/R.
Readings: ISL, Chapter 5.

title: Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
text:
Week 9-10: Tree-Based Methods

Decision trees, bagging, random forests, and boosting.
Application of tree-based models for predictive analysis in economics.

Lab: Random forests and boosting in Python/R.
Readings: ISL, Chapter 8.

title: Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
section: Week 11-12: Causal Inference Using Machine Learning
text:
Week 11-12: Causal Inference Using Machine Learning

Randomized control trials vs observational data.
Using machine learning models to predict treatment effects.

Lab: Practical causal inference examples using Python/R.
Readings: Taddy, M. (2019), Chapter 4; Angrist & Pischke (2014), Chapter 2 from Mastering ’Metrics.

title: Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
text:
Week 13-14: Unsupervised Learning

Overview of unsupervised learning techniques: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and clustering.
Applications of unsupervised learning in economics, such as market segmentation.

Lab: PCA and K-means clustering in Python/R.
Readings: ISL, Chapter 10.

title: Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
text:
Week 15: Advanced Topics and Review

Introduction to support vector machines (SVMs) and ensemble methods like boosting.
Overview of neural networks and deep learning, focusing on applications in economics.

Lab: Implementing SVMs and neural networks in Python/R.
Readings: ISL, Chapters 9-11.

title: Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
text:
Week 16: Empirical Project Presentations

Students present their final empirical projects applying machine learning to a real-world dataset.
Peer feedback and discussion.

title: Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
text:
Optional Textbooks:

Taddy, M. (2019) Business Data Science: Combining Machine Learning and Economics to Optimize Business Decisions.
ISL Gareth, J.; Witten, D.; Hastie, T.; and Tibshirani, R. (2023) An Introduction to Statistical Learning , 2nd Edition. Springer.
Angrist, J. & Pischke, J. (2014) Mastering ’Metrics: The Path from Cause to Effect.
